intro: Chaenorhinum minus subsp. pseudorubrifolium, commonly known as the red-leafed common toadflax, is a flowering plant native to southern Europe and parts of western Asia. It is a member of the family Gentianaceae and is characterized by its slender, upright stems and small, clustered flowers. The leaves are typically lance-shaped and have a reddish tinge, especially on the underside, giving the plant its common name. It thrives in sunny, well-drained soils and is often found in rocky or gravelly habitats. The plant is known for its ornamental value due to its vibrant flowers and unique foliage.
